internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
The figure given below shows a side view of a broad crested weir. The symbols shown in the figure below are defined as: Hw = the height of the weir (m), Hh = the head above the weir (m), and H = Hw + Hh = the depth of the river upstream of the weir (m).

 

%media:6.31.png%

 

The flow across the weir, Qw (m3/s), can be computed as

 

%media:formula1.mml%

 

where Cw = a weir coefficient (dimensionless), Bw = the weir width (m), and g = the gravitational constant (m/s2). Cw can be determined using the weir height (Hw) as

 

%media:formula2.mml%

 

given g = 9.81 m/s2, Hw = 0.8 m, Bw = 8 m, and Qw = 1.3 m3/s. Use the initial guess of 0.5Hw.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: The value of the upstream depth is 1.0335 m.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What is the formula for the modified secant method?

worksheet.stem:
Determine the upstream depth, H, using the modified secant method with δ = 10–5. (Round the final answer to four decimal places.)

 

The value of the upstream depth is __a__ m.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Substituting equation (2) in equation (1) and collecting terms gives

 

%media:formula3.mml%                                _____ (3)

 

The above equation can be expressed as a roots problem.

 

%media:formula4.mml%

 

Substituting parameters yield

 

%media:formula5.mml%

 

The first iteration is as follows:

 

%media:formula6.mml%     %media:formula7.mml%

 

%media:formula8.mml%     %media:formula9.mml%

 

%media:formula10.mml%

 

%media:formula11.mml%

 

The computation can be continued as shown in the following table.

 

iteration Hh f(Hh) Hh + δHh f(Hh + δHh) f'(Hh) εa
0 0.4 1.706808275 0.4000040 1.706855381 11.776700  
1 0.255069 0.190689500 0.2550716 0.190712637 9.071067 56.82%
2 0.234047 0.004549614 0.2340497 0.004569827 8.635981 8.98%
3 0.233521 0.000002932 0.2335228 0.000023073 8.624897 0.23%

 

Therefore, The value of upstream depth (H) = Hh + Hw = 0.2335 + 0.8 = 1.0335 m.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: The value of the upstream depth is 1.0336 m.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What is the formula for the fixed-point iteration method?

worksheet.stem:
Determine the upstream depth, H, using fixed-point iteration. (Round the final answer to four decimal places.)

 

The value of the upstream depth is __a__ m.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The problem can be solved with a fixed-point iteration. This is done by rearranging equation (3), so that the last Hh is brought to the left-hand side.

 

%media:formula12.mml%

 

Substituting the values from this problem gives

 

%media:formula13.mml%

 

The first iteration is as follows:

 

%media:formula14.mml%

 

%media:formula15.mml%

 

The computation can be continued as shown in the following table.

 

i xi εa
0 0.4  
1 0.22879 74.835%
2 0.23376 2.125%
3 0.23359 0.070%

 

Therefore, the value of the upstream depth (H) = Hh + Hw = 0.2336 + 0.8 = 1.0336 m.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: The value of the upstream depth is 1.0335 m.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What is the syntax of the MATLAB function, fzero?

worksheet.stem:
Determine the upstream depth, H, using the MATLAB function fzero. (Round the final answer to four decimal places.)

 

The value of the upstream depth is __a__ m.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
A script and a function can be developed to use fzero to solve this problem.

 

Function

function f = fHh(Hh,Hw,Bw,Qw)
g=9.81;
f = 1.125 * sqrt((1 + Hh / Hw) / (2 + Hh / Hw)) * ...
       Bw * sqrt(g) * (2 / 3) ^ (3 / 2) * Hh ^ (3 / 2) - Qw;

        

Script

clear,clc

Hw=0.8; Bw= 8; Qw=1.3; Hh0=0.4;

format long

[x,fx] = fzero(@fHh,Hh0,[],Hw,Bw,Qw)

 

Results

x =

  0.233520169358115

fx =

  4.441e-16

 

Therefore, the value of the upstream depth (H) = Hh + Hw = 0.2335 + 0.8 =1.0335 m.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
The following reversible chemical reaction describes how gaseous phases of methane and water react to form carbon dioxide and hydrogen in a closed reactor

 

CH4 + 2H2 O ⇔ CO2 + 4H2

 

with the equilibrium relationship

 

%media:formula16.mml%

 

where K = the equilibrium coefficient and the brackets [] designate molar concentrations (mole/L). Conservation of mass can be used to reformulate the equilibrium relationship as

 

%media:formula18.mml%

 

where x = the number of moles created in the forward direction (mole), V = the volume of the reactor (L), and Mi = the initial number of moles of constituent i (mole). It is given that K = 7 × 10−3, V = 20 L, and %media:formula19.mml%

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What is the procedure to evaluate a function using the fixed-point iteration method?

worksheet.stem:
Determine x using the fixed-point iteration method. (Round the final answer to four decimal places.)

 

The value of x is __A__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The given parameters are substituted in the equilibrium relationship and is expressed as a roots problem shown below.

 

%media:formula24.mml%

 

Consolidate terms

 

%media:formula25.mml%

 

The fixed-point iteration is as follows:

 

%media:formula27.mml%

 

For the first iteration, let x0 = 0.

 

%media:formula26.mml%

 

The iterations can be seen in the table below.

 

i xi εa
1 0  
2 0.405307 100.00%
3 0.187751 115.87%
4 0.322058 41.70%
5 0.248054 29.83%
6 0.291042 14.77%
7 0.266897 9.05%
8 0.280704 4.92%
9 0.272891 2.86%
10 0.277338 1.60%
11 0.274816 0.92%
12 0.276249 0.52%
13 0.275435 0.30%
14 0.275897 0.17%
15 0.275635 0.10%
16 0.275784 0.05%
17 0.275699 0.03%
18 0.275747 0.02%
19 0.27572 0.01%
20 0.275736 0.01%

 

Therefore, the result is 0.2757.

The concentration of pollutant bacteria c in a lake decreases according to the equation given below.

 

%media:formula20.mml%

worksheet.stem:
Determine the time required for the bacteria concentration to be reduced to 15 using the Newton-Raphson method with an initial guess of t = 6 and a stopping criterion of 1%. (Round the final answer to four decimal places.)

 

The required time is __a__ s.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
%media:formula21.mml%

 

%media:formula22.mml%

 

The first iteration is as follows:

 

%media:formula23.mml%

 

%media:formula28.mml%

 

%media:formula29.mml%

 

%media:formula30.mml%

 

The solution can be continued for 3 additional iterations to give the values tabulated below.

 

i t f(t) f'(t) |εa|
0 6 –2.61483 –1.00431  
1 3.396385 0.713495 –1.92732 76.66%
2 3.766585 0.067601 –1.59006 9.83%

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What is the syntax for the MATLAB function, fzero.

worksheet.stem:
Determine the time required for the bacteria concentration to be reduced to 15 using the MATLAB function, fzero.

 

The required time is __a__ s.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The following script can be used to calculate the required time.

 

clear,clc
format compact
[x,fx]=fzero(@(t) 77*exp(-1.5*t)+20*exp(-0.08*t)-15,0)

 

x =

    3.8095

fx =

     0

sectionBreak.stem:
A circular pipe made out of new cast iron is used to convey water at a volume flow rate of Q = 0.3 m3/s. Assume that the flow is steady and fully developed and the water is incompressible. The head loss, friction, and diameter are related by the Darcy-Weisbach equation, which is given by

 

%media:formula42.mml%

 

where f = the friction factor (dimensionless), L = length (m), D = pipe inner diameter (m), V = velocity (m/s), and g = the gravitational constant (= 9.81 m/s2). The velocity can be related to flow by

 

%media:formula43.mml%

 

where Ac = the pipe’s cross-sectional area (m2) = πD2/4, and the friction factor can be determined by the Colebrook equation, which is given below. Use the following parameter values: v = 1.16 × 10–6 m2/s and ε = 0.4 mm.

 

The Colebrook equation is given below:

 

%media:formula44.mml%.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
If you want the head loss to be less than {{[a(1)]:0.000}} m per meter of pipe, develop a MATLAB function to determine the pipe with the smallest to achieve this objective.

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)
doc.info: question data is all stored in questionProperties...

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: The value of the inner diameter is 474.18 m.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What is the syntax of the MATLAB function, fzero?

worksheet.stem:
If you want the head loss to be less than 0.006 m per meter of pipe, determine the pipe with the smallest diameter using the obtained MATLAB function to achieve this objective. (Round the final answer to two decimal places.)

 

The value of the inner diameter of the pipe is __a__ m.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
For a circular pipe, equation (2) can be solved for V as shown below.

 

%media:formula34.mml%

 

This result can be substituted into equation (1) and the result is solved for f as shown below.

 

%media:formula35.mml%

 

This result can be substituted into the Colebrook equation, which can then be formulated as a roots problem.

 

%media:formula37.mml%

 

Script

clear,clc

format compact

Q=0.3; hL=0.006; L=1; vw=1.16E-06;eps=0.4; eps=eps/1e3;d0=1;

[D,fD] = fzero(@fpipeD,d0,[],Q,hL,L,vw,eps);

D*1e3,fD

 

Function

function fd = fpipeD(d,Q,hL,L,vw,eps)

g=9.81; V=Q/(pi*d^2/4);

ed=eps/d; Re=V*d/vw;

f=d*hL*2*g/(L*V^2);

fd=2*log10(ed/3.7+2.51/Re/sqrt(f))+1/sqrt(f);

 

Results

ans =

    474.18

fD =

  -1.7764e-15

 

Therefore, the inner diameter is 474.18 m.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
The figure given below shows an asymmetric diamond-shaped supersonic airfoil. The orientation of the airfoil relative to the airflow is represented by a number of angles: α = the angle of attack, β = the shock angle, θ = the deflection angle, with the subscripts “l” and “u” designating the lower and upper surfaces of the airfoil. The following formula relates the deflection angle to the oblique shock angle and speed:

 

%media:formula38.mml%

 

%media:6.36.png%

A diamond-shaped airfoil

where, M = the Mach number, which is the ratio of the jet’s speed, v (m/s), to the speed of sound, c (m/s), where

 

%media:formula39.mml%

 

where k = the ratio of specific heats which for air is cp/cv (= 1.4), R = the air gas constant (= 287 N m/(kg K)), and Ta = the air’s absolute temperature (K). Given estimates of M, k, and θ, the shock angle can be determined as the root of

 

%media:formula40.mml%

 

The pressure on the airfoil surface, pa (kPa), can then be computed as

 

%media:formula41.mml%

 

Suppose that the airfoil is attached to a jet traveling at a speed of v = 625 m/s through air with temperature T = 4 °C, pressure p = 110 kPa, and θu = 4°.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
Develop a MATLAB script to generate a plot of f (βu) versus βu = 2° to 88°.

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)
doc.info: question data is all stored in questionProperties...

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: The pressure on the upper surface of the airfoil is 111.9713 kPa.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What is the syntax for the MATLAB function, fzero?

worksheet.stem:
Compute the pressure on the upper surface of the airfoil by developing a MATLAB script. (Round the final answer to four decimal places.)

 

The pressure on the upper surface of the airfoil is __a__ kPa.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
clear,clc
format compact
v=625;k=1.4;R=287;T=4;p=110;theta=2*pi/180;
c=sqrt(k*R*(T+273));M=v/c;
bp=[2:88]*pi/180;
fbp=fbeta(bp,k,theta,M);
plot(bp,fbp),grid
beta=180/pi*fzero(@fbeta,[2 88]*pi/180,[],k,theta,M)
pa=p*(2*k/(k+1)*(M*sin(beta))^2-(k-1)/(k+1))

 

function fb = fbeta(beta,k,theta,M)

fb=(2./tan(beta).*(M^2*sin(beta).^2-1))./(M^2*(k+cos(2*beta)+2))-tan(theta);

end

 

%media:06.36.1.png%

 

beta =

   33.98961

pa =

  111.9713

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
In a free-falling bungee jumper, for objects falling through fluids at very low speeds, the flow regime around the object will be laminar and the relationship between the drag force and velocity is linear. In addition, in such cases, the buoyancy force must also be included. For such cases, a force balance can be written as

 

%media:formula45.mml%

%media:formula84.mml%

 

where v = velocity (m/s), t = time (s), m = the mass of the particle (kg), g = the gravitational constant (= 9.81 m/s2), ρf = fluid density (kg/m3), V = particle volume (m3), and cd = the linear drag coefficient (kg/m). Note that the mass of the particle can be computed as Vρs, where ρs = the density of the particle (kg/m3). For a small sphere, Stokes developed the following formula for the drag coefficient, cd = 6πμr, where μ = the fluid’s dynamic viscosity (N s/m2) and r = the sphere’s radius (m).

 

%media:06.037.jpg%

A sphere settling in a cylinder filled with viscous honey

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Which MATLAB function is used to find the viscosity?

worksheet.stem:
Estimate the viscosity of honey based on the following parameter values: ρf = 1420 kg/m3, ρs = 7850 kg/m3, r = 0.02 m, L = 0.5 m, and t(x = 0.5) = 3.6 s. Also determine the Reynolds number (Re = ρf vd/μ, where d = diameter). (Round the final answers to four decimal places.)

 

The viscosity of honey is __a__ (N.s)/m2.

Reynolds number is __b__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
First, we can substitute m = ρsV into the given equation and collect terms to give

 

%media:formula47.mml%

 

This equation can then be integrated with the separation of variables.

 

%media:formula48.mml%

 

The integrals can be evaluated as

 

%media:formula49.mml%                                 _____ (1)

 

where C = a constant of integration, which can be evaluated by applying the initial condition, v(0) = 0.

 

%media:formula50.mml%                                           _____ (2)

 

Equation (2) can be substituted back into the solution given by equation (1).

 

%media:formula51.mml%

 

This result can be rearranged algebraically to solve for v.

 

%media:formula52.mml%

 

Now, recognizing that v = dx/dt,

 

%media:formula53.mml%

 

This equation can then be integrated with the separation of variables.

 

%media:formula54.mml%

 

which yields

 

%media:formula55.mml%

 

Applying the initial condition, x(0) = 0, gives

 

%media:formula56.mml%

 

Substituting and collecting terms yield

 

%media:formula57.mml%

 

It can be seen that viscosity can be estimated by first solving for the root of the following equation.

 


%media:formula58.mml%

 

Viscosity can then be computed as

 

%media:formula59.mml%

 

MATLAB M-files can be used to determine viscosity, and to check the Reynolds number.

 

function [fcd] = Sphere(cd,rhof,rhos,m,L,t,g)
fcd=m*g/cd*(1-rhof/rhos)*t-m^2*g/cd^2*(1-rhof/rhos)*(1-exp(-cd/m*t))-L;
end

 

clear;clc
format compact
rhof=1420;rhos=7850;r=0.02;L=0.5;t=3.6;g=9.81;
V=4/3*pi*r^3; m=rhos*V;
cd=fzero(@Sphere,12,[],rhof,rhos,m,L,t,g)
mu=cd/(6*pi*r)
vmax=m*g/cd*(1-rhof/rhos)
d=2*r;
Re=rhof*vmax*d/mu

 

Output

 

cd =

   15.1457   

mu =

   40.1753

vmax =

    0.1396

Re =

    0.1973

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: commonFeedback
property.value: The Reynolds number for the flow is found to be 0.3946. The Reynolds number is too low. Therefore, the flow is laminar.

yesNo.commonFeedback: The Reynolds number for the flow is found to be 0.3946. The Reynolds number is too low. Therefore, the flow is laminar.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The value of the deflection is 2.0494 m.

The elongation of each cable is 0.0466 m.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Can the MATLAB be used to determine the deflection and elongation?

worksheet.stem:
As shown in figure (a), a scoreboard is suspended above a sports arena by two cables, pinned at A, B, and C. The cables are initially horizontal and of length L. After the scoreboard is hung, a free-body diagram at node B can be developed as shown in figure (b). Assuming that the weight of each cable is negligible, determine the deflection, d (m), that results if the scoreboard weighs W = 9000 N. Also, compute how much each cable is elongated. Note that each cable obeys Hooke’s law such that the axial elongation is represented by L′ – L = FL /(AcE), where F = the axial force (N), Ac = the cable’s cross-sectional area (m2), and E = the modulus of elasticity (N/m2). Use the following parameters for your calculations: L = 45 m, Ac = 6.362 × 10–4 m2, and E = 1.5 × 1011 N/m2.

 

%media:06.038.jpg%

(a) Two thin cables pinned at A, B, and C with a scoreboard suspended from B

(b) Free-body diagram of the pin at B after the scoreboard is hung

(Round the final answers to four decimal places.)

 

The value of the deflection is __a__ m.

The elongation of each cable is __b__m.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Based on the free-body diagram, a vertical force balance at B can be written as

 

%media:formula60.mml%

 

Recognizing that sin θ = d/L', this equation can be solved for W as shown below.

 

%media:formula61.mml%

 

Because L' – L = FL/(AcE)

 

%media:formula62.mml%

 

which can be substituted into equation (1) to give

 

%media:formula63.mml%

 

which can be expressed as

 

%media:formula64.mml%

 

Recognizing that %media:formula65.mml%

 

%media:formula66.mml%

 

Therefore, the problem reduces to finding the root.

 

%media:formula67.mml%

 

The elongation can then be computed as follows:

 

%media:formula68.mml%

 

MATLAB M-files can be used to determine the deflection and the elongation.

function

 

function [fd] = Cable(d,W,L,Ac,E)
fd=2*Ac*E*d/L*(1-L/sqrt(L^2+d^2))-W;
end

 

Script

 

clear;clc
format compact
L=45; W=9000; Ac=0.0006362; E=1.50E+11;
deflection=fzero(@Cable,3,[],W,L,Ac,E)
elongation=sqrt(L^2+deflection^2)-L

 

When the script is run, the result is

 

deflection =
            2.0494
elongation =
            0.0466

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
A water tower is connected to a pipe with a valve at its end, as depicted in the given figure. Under a number of simplifying assumptions (for example, minor friction losses neglected), the following energy balance can be written as

 

%media:formula69.mml%

 

where g = gravitational acceleration (= 9.81 m/s2), h = tower height (m), v = mean water velocity in pipe (m/s), f = the pipe’s friction factor, L = the horizontal pipe length (m), d = pipe diameter (m), Le,e = equivalent length for the elbow (m), Le,v = equivalent length for the valve (m), and K = loss coefficient for the contraction at the bottom of the tank. Use the following parameter values: h = 24 m, L = 65 m, d = 100 mm, Le,e∕d = 30, Le,v∕d = 8, and K = 0.5; the kinematic viscosity of water is v = μ/ρ = 1.2 × 10–6 m2/s.

 

%media:06.039.jpg%

A water tower connected to a pipe with a valve at its end

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
Write a MATLAB script to determine the flow exiting the valve.

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)
doc.info: question data is all stored in questionProperties...

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: The flow existing the valve is 0.0311 m<sup>3</sup>/s.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Which MATLAB function is used to find the flow existing the valve?

worksheet.stem:
Determine the flow exiting the valve, Q(m3/s), using the developed MATLAB script. (Round the final answer to four decimal places.)

 

The flow existing the valve is __a__ m3/s.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Function

 

function ft = ftank(v,h,L,d,Lee_d,Lev_d,K,nu,e_d)
global g
f = Colebrook(v,d,nu,e_d);
ft=g*h-v^2/2-f*((L+h)/d+Lee_d+Lev_d)*v^2/2-K*v^2/2;
end

function f = Colebrook(v,d,nu,e_d)
global g
Re=v*d/nu;
ff=@(f) 1/sqrt(f)+2*log10(e_d/3.7+2.51/(Re*sqrt(f)));
f=fzero(ff,.05);
end

 

Script

 

clear,clc
global g
format compact
g=9.81;
h = 24; L = 65; d = .1; Lee_d = 30; Lev_d = 8;
K = 0.5; nu = 1.2e-6; e_d=0.005;
v=fzero(@ftank,1,[],h,L,d,Lee_d,Lev_d,K,nu,e_d)
Q=v*pi*d^2/4
f=Colebrook(v,d,nu,e_d)

 

Output

 

v =
    3.9650
Q =
    0.0311
f =
    0.0307

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
Consider the following MATLAB function:

 

function b = fzerosimp(xl,xu)
a = xl; b = xu; fa = f(a); fb = f(b);
c = a; fc = fa; d = b − c; e = d;
while (1)
  if fb == 0, break, end
  if sign(fa) == sign(fb) %If needed, rearrange points
   a = c; fa = fc; d = b − c; e = d;
  end
  if abs(fa) < abs(fb)
    c = b; b = a; a = c;
    fc = fb; fb = fa; fa = fc;
  end
  m = 0.5*(a − b); %Termination test and possible exit
  tol = 2 * eps * max(abs(b), 1);
  if abs(m) <= tol | fb == 0.
    break
  end
  %Choose open methods or bisection
  if abs(e) >= tol & abs(fc) > abs(fb)
    s = fb/fc;
    if a == c     %Secant method
      p = 2*m*s;
      q = 1 − s;
    else %Inverse quadratic interpolation
      q = fc/fa; r = fb/fa;
      p = s * (2*m*q * (q − r) − (b − c)*(r − 1));
      q = (q − 1)*(r − 1)*(s − 1);
    end
    if p > 0, q = −q; else p = −p; end;
    if 2*p < 3*m*q − abs(tol*q) & p < abs(0.5*e*q)
      e = d; d = p/q;
    else
      d = m; e = m;
    end
  else %Bisection
    d = m; e = m;
  end
  c = b; fc = fb;
  if abs(d) > tol, b = b + d; else b = b−sign(b − a)*tol; end
  fb = f(b);
end

 

Determining fluid flow through pipes and tubes has great relevance. The resistance to flow in such conduits is parameterized by a dimensionless number called the friction factor. For turbulent flow, the Colebrook equation provides a means to calculate the friction factor.

 

%media:formula70.mml%

 

where ε = the roughness (m), D = diameter (m), Re = the Reynolds number.

 

%media:formula71.mml%

 

where, ρ = the fluid’s density (kg/m3), V = its velocity (m/s), and μ = dynamic viscosity (N · s/m2). In addition to appearing in the above equation, the Reynolds number also serves as the criterion for whether flow is turbulent (Re > 4000). For this case, the parameters are ρ = 1.23 kg/m3, μ = 1.79 × 10–5 N · s/m2, D = 0.005 m, V = 40 m/s, and ε = 0.0015 mm. Note that friction factors range from about 0.008 to 0.08.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
Modify the given fzerosimp function, so that it can be passed any function with a single unknown and uses varargin to pass the function’s parameters.

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)
doc.info: question data is all stored in questionProperties...

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What is the syntax of the MATLAB function fzerosimp?

worksheet.stem:
Use the modified function developed in the previous question of the same section, to obtain a solution for the given pipe friction using the following script.

 

clc
format long, format compact
rho = 1.23;mu = 1.79e − 5;D=0.005;V = 40;e = 0.0015/1000;
Re = rho*V*D/mu;
g = @(f,e,D) 1/sqrt(f)+2*log10(e/(3.7*D)+2.51/(Re*sqrt(f)));
f = fzerosimp(@(x) g(x,e,D),0.008,0.08)

 

(Round the final answer to five decimal places.)

 

The solution is __a__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Modified MATLAB function is

 

function b = fzerosimp(f,xl,xu,varargin)
a = xl; b = xu; fa = f(a,varargin{:}); fb = f(b,varargin{:});
c = a; fc = fa; d = b - c; e = d;
while (1)
  if fb == 0, break, end
  if sign(fa) == sign(fb) %If needed, rearrange points
    a = c; fa = fc; d = b - c; e = d;
  end
  if abs(fa) < abs(fb)
    c = b; b = a; a = c;
    fc = fb; fb = fa; fa = fc;
  end
  m = 0.5*(a - b); %Termination test and possible exit
  tol = 2 * eps * max(abs(b), 1);
  if abs(m) <= tol | fb == 0.
    break
  end
  %Choose open methods or bisection
  if abs(e) >= tol & abs(fc) > abs(fb)
    s = fb/fc;
    if a == c %Secant method
      p = 2*m*s;
      q = 1 - s;
    else %Inverse quadratic interpolation
      q = fc/fa; r = fb/fa;
      p = s * (2*m*q * (q - r) - (b - c)*(r - 1));
      q = (q - 1)*(r - 1)*(s - 1);
    end
    if p > 0, q = -q; else p = -p; end;
      if 2*p < 3*m*q - abs(tol*q) & p < abs(0.5*e*q)
        e = d; d = p/q;
      else
d = m; e = m;
      end
    else %Bisection
      d = m; e = m;
    end
    c = b; fc = fb;
    if abs(d) > tol, b=b+d; else b=b-sign(b-a)*tol; end
    fb = f(b,varargin{:});
end

 

Script

 

clc
format long, format compact
rho=1.23;mu=1.79e-5;D=0.005;V=40;e=0.0015/1000;
Re=rho*V*D/mu;
g=@(f,e,D) 1/sqrt(f)+2*log10(e/(3.7*D)+2.51/(Re*sqrt(f)));
f=fzerosimp(@(x) g(x,e,D),0.008,0.08)

 

Output

 

f =
   0.028967810171441
